thread.title: Cameron's EU Renegotiation Must Deliver Soon
thread.title_full: Cameron's EU Renegotiation Must Deliver Soon

author: news.sky
title: Cameron's EU Renegotiation Must Deliver Soon
text:
The likelihood of a quick referendum on EU membership is receding rapidly, as the renegotiation proceeds slowly. Senior government sources are playing down the notion that the December European Council will be "high noon" for the debate.
The deal-making is likely to seep into 2016, which could see a referendum in 2017.
The current state of play in the great European renegotiation has been described to me by a Cabinet minister as "at the moment a type of mating ritual where we are dancing around each other".
The UK and EU partners have been involved in a ritual that is noteworthy for revealing very little.
Play video "EU In Or Out: In Numbers" Video: EU In Or Out: In Numbers Specifically, the lack of willingness of the UK side to reveal a written-down list of ideas has led to much bafflement.
Many of David Cameron's interlocutors, in the admittedly impressive charm offensive he has launched since re-election, remain generally supportive.
:: Leaving EU Is A 'Leap In The Dark', Warns Rose 
Some have reported he asked them for ideas, and was content with receiving public statements that the relevant European Union leader "wants Britain to stay in the EU". That was never up for debate.
The mating ritual also applies to the weekly technical talks hosted by the European Council's lawyers in Brussels over the summer.
1 / 7 Gallery: EU Vote: Who Is On Team In
The Britain is Stronger in Europe campaign is being headed by the former M&S boss Lord Rose
This week, President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, will present early details of these technicalities.
The principal diplomatic cause of slow progress was an acceptance by the UK that controversial reforms to EU citizen eligibility for UK tax credits would not be pushed before the Polish elections next week.
Mr Cameron's diplomacy will then pick up again in November.
The four broad parameters of the negotiation are limits on migration benefits, strengthening the single market, an opt out from 'ever closer union' and a fundamental and fair settlement within the EU between the euro-outs and euro-ins.
These changes need to have "irreversible" legal underpinning, but treaty change pre-referendum is not possible.
1 / 8 Gallery: EU Vote: Who Is On Team Out
The Vote Out team has the support of a number of political donors. Among them is 80-year-old spread-betting millionaire and UKIP donor Stuart Wheeler
It was highly significant that even Mr Cameron's key centre right ally, new Danish PM Lars Lokke Rasmussen, told me last month in Downing Street that treaty change "is not very realistic".
Mr Rasmussen had praised the UK renegotiation in the Danish election campaign.
In this respect, the fact that the official campaign chaired by Lord Rose launched on Monday morning with the respected retailer saying he would vote to stay in "come what may" is significant.
Lord Rose also suggested he would not be the man to front up leave/remain TV debates.
That role might just be being left for the PM - in which case his renegotiation surely has to deliver soon.
